newsitem.title: JAPAN: E.Asian Grain - Buyers brace for USDA report.
newsitem.headline: E.Asian Grain - Buyers brace for USDA report.

text.p: East Asian grain buyers are largely holding back on their corn purchases ahead of key impending U.S. agricultural data, dealers said on Monday.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) quarterly stocks and planting intentions report is due out later in the day.

"We're more interested in stocks rather than planting intentions. Local feed makers are likely to enter the market if the USDA announces bullish figures," a corn trader at a major trade house in Japan said.
Japanese dealers have already finished buying their April/June requirements of U.S. corn, but so far have only covered 10 percent of their July/September shipments.
Premiums were quoted at between 93 to 94 U.S. cents a bushel over the CBOT May contract, they said.
In South Korea, dealers said local buyers were a little leery of the USDA report and were largely staying on the sidelines having already covered most of their needs up to August shipment.
"Most of our clients will take some break since they have covered their requirements for far forward shipments to August," a trader with a foreign grain trading house in Seoul said.

Elsewhere in the East Asian grains market, the Philippines is to tender, on a a snap basis, for 40,000 tonnes of corn for mid-April shipment and local traders confirmed the purchase by two mills of 100,000 tonnes of Canadian wheat.
The Taiwanese feed market remains battered by the effects of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease which has ravaged the pork industry and is likely to cause a sharp drop in demand.
"Feed producers are still working on reducing their corn and soybean inventories," Taiwan Formosa Oilseed manager Steven Kuo told Reuters.
Major Taiwanese grain importers said they expect a reduction in corn imports of about 1.2 million tonnes, or 19 percent of the island's 6.5 million tonnes of imports each year.

Regional demand for Chinese corn though, remains generally good on attractive prices relative to U.S.-origin and South Korean buyers dismissed talk of imports from China being pinched by logistical log jams.
"We have not seen any problem with Chinese corn deliveries to our clients," one trader in Seoul said.
A trader with South Korea's National Livestock Cooperatives Federation (NLCF) also dismissed the market talk.
"We have heard (of) the rumour but there is no problem."
Since January, South Korean buyers have bought at least 1.022 million tonnes of Chinese corn through tenders and private negotiations, traders said.
China is also still offering corn to Japan at a quote of about US$135-$136 a tonne FOB Dalian, traders said. About two local traders have bought corn from this origin, they said.
But other Japanese buyers are holding off believing Chinese offers are still too high.

"Chinese corn is not cheap enough, with freight costs around $20 (a tonne) China is just trying to export corn to solve their storage problem in corn growing regions, not to earn hard currency," another corn trader in Tokyo said.
South Korean flour makers Cheiljedang Corp and Dongah Flour Mills Co Ltd are expected to tender this week to buy 23,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat for shipment between May 5 to June 5, traders said.
The freight rate from the Pacific Northwest to South Korea was unchanged at $15.50 a tonne, while the rate from the U.S. Gulf was also flat at $25.50 a tonne.
In Taiwan, Pacific Northwest freight costs were seen at about $14.00 a tonne while quotes from the Gulf of Mexico ranged between $24.00 and $25.00 a tonne, both for Panamax-sized March shipments.
